choices.text: Outlet Forceps can be applied
Best time to give episiotomy
Called as crowning
May lead to deep transverse arrest

questions.text: When the fetal head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Outlet Forceps can be applied

 

Outlet Forceps can be applied:  This is True. When the fetal skull has reached the level of pelvic floor and head is on the perineum, outlet forceps can be applied.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Best time to give episotomy: This is not entirely true.  Best time to give episiotomy is at the time of crowning of head. However, crowning is defined as stretching of the vulval outlet by the maximum diameter of the fetal head (biparietal diameter) without any recession.
  • Option C: Called as crowning: This is not true. crowning is defined as stretching of the vulval outlet by the maximum diameter of the fetal head (biparietal diameter) without any recession. The station is + 3
  • Option D) May lead to deep transverse arrest : Not true . In deep transverse arrest station at O, as the sagittal suture is in transverse bispinous diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the fetal head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor, it is an appropriate time to consider the application of outlet forceps to assist in the delivery of the baby's head.

 

Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 23y primigravida is undergoing an elective LSCS for breech presentation. What is the ideal timing of cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 39 Weeks

 

Elective LSCS is best planned at 39 weeks as adverse neonatal sequelae from neonatal immaturity are appreciable before 39 weeks.

 

Indications for LSCS

 

Maternal

 

  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Abnormal placentation
  • Maternal request
  • Prior classical hysterotomy
  • Unknown uterine scar type
  • Prior uterine incision dehiscence
  • Prior full-thickness myomectomy
  • Genital tract obstructive mass
  • Invasive cervical cancer
  • Prior trachelectomy
  • Permanent cerclage
  • Prior significant perineal trauma
  • Pelvic deformity
  • HSV or HIV infection
  • Cardiac or pulmonary disease
  • Cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation
  • Pathology requiring concurrent intraabdominal surgery
  • Perimortem cesarean delivery

 

Maetrnal-Fetal

 

  • Cephalopevic disproportion
  • Failed operative vaginal delivery
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Placental abrupton

 

Fetal

 

  • Nonreassuring fetal status
  • Malpresentation
  • Macrosomia
  • Congenital anomaly
  • Abnormal umbilical cord Doppler study
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Prior neonatal birth trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal timing for elective cesarean sections should consider the balance between fetal maturity and the avoidance of complications associated with preterm or post-term birth. In the case of a primigravida with a breech presentation, scheduling the cesarean section around 39 weeks of gestation is often recommended to optimize the baby's readiness for birth while minimizing the risk of neonatal complications.

 

Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Fully dilated cervix

questions.text: Prerequisite for outlet forceps application are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Station 0 or +1

 

  • The outlet forceps are applied when station of fetal head is ≥ +3 station and not at 0 or +1.

 

 

 

Let's look at each option :

 

  • Option A. Engaged head: An engaged head means that the baby's head has descended into the maternal pelvis. This is typically a prerequisite for outlet forceps application because it ensures that the baby's head is low in the birth canal, making it accessible for the forceps to be applied safely.
  • Option B. Fully dilated cervix: A fully dilated cervix means that the cervix has opened completely, typically to 10 cm in diameter. A fully dilated cervix is necessary before using forceps.
  • Option C. Uterus contracting: The presence of uterine contractions aid in the delivery process.
  • Option D: Station 0 or +1: Station refers to the position of the baby's head in the birth canal in relation to the mother's pelvis. The outlet forceps are applied when station of fetal head is ≥ +3 station and not at 0 or +1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's important to assess the engagement of the fetal head, cervical dilation, the presence of uterine contractions, and the station of the baby's head to determine the appropriate timing for forceps application during childbirth. The outlet forceps are applied when station of fetal head is ≥ +3 station and not at 0 or +1.

 

Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 39 y primigravida female presents in labor with breech presentation at 38 weeks. She has conceived via IVF. She has multiple large fibroids in the anterior lower uterine segment. The most appropriate management is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Classical cesarean

 

  • This woman has presented with breech presentation (primi breech) and is an IVF conception. She also has multiple large fibroids in the lower part of the uterus. She would best delivered by a cesarean section.
  • The lower uterine segment is not going to be approachable due to multiple large fibroids in the lower segment. Hence classical cesarean section (upper segment cesarean) should be done.
  • Indications of Classical cesarean (upper segment cesarean)
    • Fibroids in the lower segment
    • Adhesions in the lower segment
    • Placenta accreta syndromes
    • Cervical cancer
    • Post trachelectomy
  • Upper segment cesarean is closed in 3 layers as shown
  • Also remember that risk of rupture uterus in subsequent pregnancies is highest following a classical cesarean (4-9%)

 

 

 

Let us look at the remaining options:

 

  • Option A. Vaginal delivery: Vaginal delivery is generally not recommended for breech presentations in primigravida women, especially when there are additional complications such as multiple large fibroids in the anterior lower uterine segment.
  • Option B. Trial of labor: A trial of labor may be considered in some cases, but it is generally not advisable for a primigravida with a breech presentation and multiple large fibroids in the lower uterine segment.
  • Option C. Lower segment cesarean: A cesarean section is often recommended for breech presentations, especially in primigravida women, as it reduces the risks associated with delivering a baby in a breech position. The lower uterine segment is not going to be approachable due to multiple large fibroids in the lower segment. Hence classical cesarean section (upper segment cesarean) should be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A cesarean section is often recommended for breech presentations, especially in primigravida women, as it reduces the risks associated with delivering a baby in a breech position.
  • When the lower uterine segment is not approachable due to multiple large fibroids in the lower segment, classical cesarean section (upper segment cesarean) may be done.
  • Indications for a classical cesarean section include:
    • Large fibroid in the lower segment
    • Dense adhesions in the lower segmenr
    • Placenta accreta syndrome
    • Carcinoma cervix
    • Perimortem cesarean section

 

Ref: Page no 1442, Willaims Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Previous lower segment transverse cesarean
Presence of inverted ‘T’-shaped uterine incision
Where facilities for emergency cesareans are not available

questions.text: All are the contraindications for vaginal birth after previous cesarean except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Previous lower segment transverse cesarean

 

Vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) means a successful vaginal birth in a woman who has had a previous cesarean(s)

 

Trial of Labor after Cesarean (ToLAC) means allowing a woman who has had a previous cesarean (s) to undergo labor

 

Contra-indications to Trial of Labor After Cesarean (TOLAC) include

 

  • Previous classical cesarean
  • Previous inverted T incision or extension of the incision into the upper segment
  • Cephalo-pelvic disproportion
  • Malpresentations
  • Placenta previa
  • No emergency care facilities
  • Non reassuring fetal status 

 

Table: Types of Prior Uterine Incisions and Estimated Risks for Uterine Rupture

 

 

Let us look at each option:

 

  • Option A. Previous classical uterine incision: A classical uterine incision is a vertical incision made on the upper part of the uterus. It is a contraindication for vaginal birth after previous cesarean (VBAC) because the risk of uterine rupture during labor is higher with this type of incision.
  • Option B. Previous lower segment transverse cesarean: A lower segment transverse cesarean section (LSCS) involves a horizontal incision made on the lower part of the uterus. This type of uterine incision is not a contraindication for VBAC.
  • Option C. Presence of inverted ‘T’-shaped uterine incision: An inverted 'T'-shaped uterine incision is a less common type of incision used for specific surgical indications. It is generally considered a contraindication for VBAC because it carries an increased risk of uterine rupture during a subsequent vaginal birth.
  • Option D. Where facilities for emergency cesareans are not available This is an essential safety consideration. It is essential to have facilities for emergency cesareans readily available in case an urgent intervention becomes necessary during a VBAC trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While VBAC can be a safe option for some women with a previous cesarean section, certain factors, such as the type of previous uterine incision and the availability of emergency resources, need to be considered to make informed decisions about the mode of delivery.

 

Ref:  Page 1492, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Atonic uterus with uncontrolled PPH

questions.text: Indications for cesarean hysterectomy are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Couvelaire uterus

 

  • Cesarean hysterectomy refers to an operation where cesarean section is followed by removal of the uterus.
  • Obstetric hysterectomy (peripartum hysterectomy) is the surgical removal of the uterus either at the time of cesarean delivery or in the immediate postpartum period (even following vaginal delivery).
  • Couvelaire uterus: A Couvelaire uterus, also known as uteroplacental apoplexy or abruptio placentae with concealed hemorrhage, refers to a situation where there is severe bleeding within the uterine wall due to a placental abruption. While this condition is a medical emergency, the treatment typically involves addressing the hemorrhage and managing the underlying cause, which may not necessarily require a cesarean hysterectomy.

 

 

Remember: Couvelaire uterus (as seen after abruptio placenta) is not an indication for

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Placenta accreta: Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is adherent to the uterine wall. This can lead to significant bleeding during delivery and can be a valid indication for cesarean hysterectomy.
  • Option C. Atonic uterus with uncontrolled PPH: An atonic uterus refers to a uterus that fails to contract effectively after childbirth, which can result in postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). When medical interventions to control PPH are unsuccessful, a cesarean hysterectomy may be performed as a life-saving measure.
  • Option D. Ruptured uterus: A ruptured uterus is a serious obstetric emergency and can result in severe bleeding and which can compromise well-being. In cases of uterine rupture, a cesarean hysterectomy may be performed to control bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Caesarean hysterectomy is  a life-saving measure in cases of severe obstetric emergencies such as placenta accreta, atonic uterus with uncontrolled PPH, or ruptured uterus.

 

 Page 1910 Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Severe continuous abdominal pain
Fresh vaginal bleeding

questions.text: A second Para who has had an uncomplicated lower segment cesarean section in her first pregnancy is in labor. She is allowed a trial of vaginal delivery. What is the earliest warning sign of scar rupture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fetal distress

 

  • Earliest sign of scar rupture is fetal bradycardia i.e. change in FHR i.e. fetal distress (Fetal tachycardia/ bradycardia/ late decelerations)
  • Other signs
    • Scar tenderness (tenderness elicited on suprapubic palpation)
    • Maternal tachycardia
  • Once frank rupture happens, there is
    • Maternal Hypotension, signs of shock
    • Sudden cessation of uterine contractions
    • Absent fetal hearts
    • Fetal parts felt easily
    • Uterus contracted, felt separately
    • Fresh vaginal bleeding
    • Loss of station on vaginal examination
    • Hematuria.
       

Other Options

 

  • Option A: Severe continuous abdominal pain: Severe continuous abdominal pain can be a sign of uterine scar rupture, but it is not typically the earliest sign. It often occurs after the rupture has progressed
  • Option C. Fresh vaginal bleeding: Fresh vaginal bleeding can occur as a result of scar rupture, but it may not always be the earliest sign. Nonetheless, any fresh vaginal bleeding in a woman with a history of LSCS should be evaluated promptly.
  • Option D: Maternal tachycardia: Maternal tachycardia can occur in response to various stressors, including uterine scar rupture. However, it is not typically the earliest warning sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal distress, as manifested by changes in the fetal heart rate pattern, is often one of the earliest and most significant warning signs



Ref: Page 149, 6Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Aftercoming head in breech
Internal rotation incomplete

questions.text: Contraindication of vacuum extraction are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Internal rotation incomplete

 

  • Ventouse/Vacuum extraction: Ventouse is an instrument which assists in delivery by creating a vacuum between it and fetal scalp.
  • Vacuum/ forceps are applied when there is
    • Prolonged 2nd stage
    • Fetal distress in 2nd stage
    • Cutting short the 2nd stage of labor for maternal benefit (eclampsia/ severe anemia/ heart disease etc).

 

Pre-requisites for forceps delivery: Mnemonic is FORCEPS

 

 

Contraindications for vacuum extraction are:

 

  1. Prematurity
  2. Fetal Coagulopathy
  3. Nonengaged fetal head
  4. CPD (Cephalopelvic disproportion)
  5. After coming head of Breech
  6. Face presentation

 

Let us look at each option :

 

  • Option A: Mento-anterior presentation: Mento-anterior presentation refers to the position of the baby's head where the face is the presenting part during delivery. It is  a contraindication for vacuum extraction.
  • Option B. Aftercoming head in breech: When the baby is in the breech position, vacuum extraction is generally contraindicated.
  • Option C. Floating head: A "floating head" is a term used to describe a situation where the baby's head is not well-engaged in the birth canal, and it can move freely within the pelvis. Vacuum extraction is contraindicated when the baby's head is floating .
  • Option D: Internal rotation incomplete: Internal rotation refers to the movement of the baby's head within the birth canal during the second stage of labor. This is not a contraindication, unlike forceps vacuum does not need complete rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vacuum can be applied even when internal rotation is incomplete.

 

ReF: Page 1392, Wiliams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps
Can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine
Maternal trauma is more frequent than forceps
Cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotated

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding Ventouse (vacuum extractor)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps
 

Remember in Vacuum

 

  • Fetal trauma is more than maternal trauma (In forceps, maternal trauma > fetal trauma)
  • Vacuum has a feature of autorotation; so even if internal rotation is not complete – traction on the vacuum will cause rotation
  • Vacuum is applied only if the head is below the ischial spines (head should not be palpable on abdominal examination)
  • Vacuum is applied on the flexion point; this is a point which lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanella. In simple terms, the closer the vacuum cup is applied to the post part of the head, flexion will happen. IF it is placed anteriorly, extension of the ehad wil happen and delivery will be unsuccessful.

 

 

Let us look at each option

 

  • Option A. Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps: This statement is true. Vacuum extraction can result in minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in the newborn more frequently compared to forceps. The vacuum cup attaches to the baby's head, and the negative pressure used to assist in the delivery can occasionally cause these minor injuries
  • Option B. Can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine: This is False. Successful vacuum extraction is more likely when the fetal head is lower in the birth canal.
  • Option C. Maternal trauma is more frequent than forceps: This is False. Forceps may pose a higher risk of maternal trauma, such as perineal tears or injury, compared to vacuum extraction.
  • Option D. Cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotated: This is False. While the optimal position for vacuum extraction is when the fetal head is fully rotated and well-engaged in the birth canal, it is possible to attempt vacuum extraction when the head is not fully rotated.
     

Educational Objective:

 

  • It is important to weigh the benefits and risks of using vacuum extraction in each case, considering factors such as fetal position, maternal condition, and the potential for minor newborn injuries. Vacuum has a feature of autorotation; so even if internal rotation is not complete – traction on the vacuum will cause rotation

 

Ref: Page no 1395, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Untreated stage of I B Ca cervix

questions.text: The following is always an indication of cesarean section except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abruptio placentae

 

Cesarean Section is not indicated in all cases of abruptio placentae.

 

  • In Abruption, the aim is to expedite delivery by whichever way is quicker and depending on the maternal and fetal condition
  • In carcinoma cervix, classical cesarean section should be done. Vaginal delivery should not be allowed because of cervical dystocia and injuries.
  • Cesarean section is indicated in an active primary genital HSV infection. This is to avoid neonatal herpes which can happen as there is viral shedding in the lesions which can transfer to fetus during vaginal delivery.
  • In severe degree of placenta previa (Type II posterior, Type III or Type IV), cesarean section is indicated for maternal interest even if the baby is dead.

 

Indications for LSCS

 

Maternal

 

  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Abnormal placentation
  • Maternal request
  • Prior classical hysterotomy
  • Unknown uterine scar type
  • Prior uterine incision dehiscence
  • Prior full-thickness myomectomy
  • Genital tract obstructive mass
  • Invasive cervical cancer
  • Prior trachelectomy
  • Permanent cerclage
  • Prior significant perineal trauma
  • Pelvic deformity
  • HSV or HIV infection
  • Cardiac or pulmonary disease
  • Cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation
  • Pathology requiring concurrent intraabdominal surgery
  • Perimortem cesarean delivery

 

Maetrnal-Fetal

 

  • Cephalopevic disproportion
  • Failed operative vaginal delivery
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Placental abrupton

 

Fetal

 

  • Nonreassuring fetal status
  • Malpresentation
  • Macrosomia
  • Congenital anomaly
  • Abnormal umbilical cord Doppler study
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Prior neonatal birth trauma.


Let's go through each of the options :

 

Option A. Abruptio Placentae: Abruptio placentae refers to the premature separation of the placenta. The mode of delivery in cases of placental abruption depends on the severity of the abruption, the gestational age, fetal condition, and the amount of bleeding. In some cases, if the fetus is stable and the bleeding is controlled, vaginal delivery might be possible.

 

Option B. Untreated Stage of I B Ca Cervix: Stage IB cervical cancer refers to a localized cancer that has not spread beyond the cervix. If a woman is pregnant and has this diagnosis, the decision about the mode of delivery is complex. In some cases, a C-section might be recommended to avoid disrupting the cancerous tissue during vaginal delivery, which could potentially spread cancer cells.

 

Option C. Active Primary Genital Herpes: Active genital herpes during delivery can pose a risk of transmitting the virus to the baby during a vaginal birth, particularly if it's a primary infection. The herpes simplex virus can cause serious complications in newborns, including neonatal herpes, which can be fatal. Therefore, a C-section is typically recommended to reduce the risk of transmission if the mother has active genital lesions or prodromal symptoms at the time of delivery.

 

Option D. Type IV Placenta Previa (Major Previa): Type IV placenta previa, also known as major or complete previa, occurs when the placenta completely covers the cervix. This condition poses a significant risk of haemorrhage during labor and delivery. Vaginal delivery in this scenario is almost always contraindicated because of the high risk of severe bleeding, which can be life-threatening for both the mother and the baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's important to recognize that while some conditions (like major placenta previa and active genital herpes) commonly necessitate a C-section, others (like placental abruption) require a more nuanced approach based on individual circumstances.

 

Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A forceps rotation of 30° from left occiput anterior (OA) to OA with extraction of the fetus from +2 station would be described as which type of delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Low forceps

 

 

Let's look at each option:

 

  • Option A: Outlet Forceps: Outlet forceps delivery is indicated when the baby's head is at the pelvic floor, and the sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or its right or left oblique diameter, with the fetal head at or on the perineum
  • Option B: Low Forceps: Low forceps delivery is indicated when the leading point of the skull is at station +2 or more but not on the pelvic floor. In this case, the baby's head is low in the pelvis but not as low as with outlet forceps.
  • Option C: Mid Forceps: Mid forceps delivery is when the head is engaged in the maternal pelvis but not descended to +2 station. This type of forceps delivery is more complicated and carries greater risks than low or outlet forceps delivery. It's generally less preferred due to the increased potential for maternal and fetal injury.
  • Option D: High Forceps: High forceps delivery is a historical term and is no longer practiced. It referred to the application of forceps when the fetal head was not yet engaged in the maternal pelvis. This procedure was associated with high risks of injury to both the mother and the baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Outlet forceps delivery is indicated when the fetal head is at or on the perineum. Low forceps delivery is indicated when the leading point of the skull is at station +2 or more but not on the pelvic floor.

 

Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Less chance of extension
Lesser blood loss

questions.text: An episiotomy is to be performed in a primigravida in labor. Which of these is an advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Less chance of extension

 

Episiotomy

 


 

  • So basically, the only advantage of a mediolateral episiotomy is less extension, but this is also the main reason why we prefer to use a mediolateral episiotomy compared to a midline episiotomy.

 

Let us look at each option:
 

  • Option A: Less Chance of Extension (Answer A): A mediolateral episiotomy is angled away from the anus, which reduces the risk of the incision extending into the anal sphincter or the rectum during childbirth. This is particularly important in reducing the risk of severe perineal trauma, such as third- or fourth-degree tears, which are more likely with midline episiotomies.
  • Option B: Less Dyspareunia: Dyspareunia refers to painful sexual intercourse. Studies have shown mixed results regarding the type of episiotomy and the risk of dyspareunia. Some studies suggest that midline episiotomies might be associated with a lower risk of dyspareunia compared to mediolateral episiotomies.
  • Option C: Fewer Breakdowns: Wound breakdown refers to the reopening of a surgical incision after it has started to heal. The risk of wound breakdown can be influenced by several factors, including the type of episiotomy, but there isn't a clear consensus that one type of episiotomy leads to significantly fewer breakdowns than the other.
  • Option D: Lesser Blood Loss:  Typically, midline episiotomies are thought to cause less blood loss compared to mediolateral episiotomies, as the latter involves cutting through more vascular tissues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A mediolateral episiotomy is associated with less chances of extension, compared to a midline episiotomy.

 

Ref: Page 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Episiotomy scissor

 

This is a Braun episiotomy scissor. It is non ratcheted finger ring scissors, angled with smooth, blunt/ blunt tips, and has a length of 5-1/2 inches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C: Babcock’s forceps: Finger ring ratcheted, non-perforating atraumatic forceps used to grasp tubular and delicate structures

 

 

Option D: Ovum forceps: It doesn’t have lock, used to remove retained products of conception.

 

 

 

  • Option B: Cutting Scissors: Cutting scissors in a medical context can refer to various types of scissors used for cutting tissues during surgery. These can include standard surgical scissors, which are typically straight or curved with sharp blades, used for general cutting purposes in various surgical procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors have a unique design that typically includes a blunt tip on one or both blades to prevent injury to the baby and mother. They often have a curved or angled shape to facilitate the incision in the perineal area.

 

Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip
Trendelenburg with legs in stirrup

questions.text: A pregnant female presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is taken for a cesarean section. What is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on OT table?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Supine with wedge under right hip

 

  • In caesarean section, patient is placed in supine position.
  • In order to prevent venocaval compression (supine hypotension syndrome), 15-degree tilt is given by placing a wedge under the right hip till delivery of the baby.

 

 

Let’s review the options:

 

Option A. Supine with Wedge under Right Hip: This is the correct position for a cesarean section. Placing a wedge under the right hip, also known as the left lateral tilt, helps to prevent aortocaval compression by the uterus. Aortocaval compression can occur when the pregnant uterus compresses the inferior vena cava and the aorta, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension, which can be harmful to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Option B. Semi Fowler's Position: This position, where the patient is partially sitting up, is not typically used for cesarean sections. While it can be comfortable for labor and delivery under certain circumstances, it is not suitable for a cesarean section, which requires access to the abdominal area.

 

Option C. Trendelenburg with Legs in Stirrup: The Trendelenburg position involves lying on the back with the body tilted so that the feet are higher than the head. While this position might be used in certain surgical procedures, it is not appropriate for a cesarean section as it can increase aortocaval compression and is not conducive to optimal surgical access.

 

Option D. Prone Position: The prone position, where the patient lies flat on their stomach, is not used for cesarean sections. This position is inappropriate for abdominal surgery and would be unsafe for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct position for a woman undergoing a cesarean section is A, Supine with a Wedge under the Right Hip. This positioning minimizes aortocaval compression, ensuring better blood flow and oxygenation for both the mother and the fetus, and provides the surgeon with appropriate access to perform the cesarean section safely and effectively.

 

Ref: Page 1413, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A resident is teaching the intern how to apply a vacuum in the 2nd stage of labor. After applying the cup at the flexion point, the intern feels around the cup to make sure no maternal tissue is entrapped. Then the vacuum apparatus is turned on to created pressure.  What is the maximum pressure created in vacuum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 0.8 kg/cm2

 

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN FORCEPS AND VACUUM

 

 

Remember: Both need full dilatation to be applied

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct pressure used in vacuum-assisted deliveries is  0.8 kg/cm. This level of pressure is considered safe and effective for assisting in the delivery of a baby during the second stage of labor.

 

Ref : Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th Edition page:563

questions.text: Conditions which are contraindicated for vacuum extractions are all; EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Occipito-posterior position

 

The contraindications for a vacuum are:

 

  1. Face or other non vertex presentation
  2. Prematurity
  3. Fetal coagulopathies
  4. Following recent scalp blood sampling
  5. After coming head in breech
  6. Intra uterine fetal demise

 

Let us examine each option:

 

  • Option A: Face Presentation: In a face presentation, the baby's face is the presenting part in the birth canal. Vacuum extraction in this scenario is contraindicated because the vacuum cup cannot be properly and safely applied to the baby's head.
  • Option B. Extreme Prematurity: The bones of the skull in extremely premature infants are not yet fully developed and are more susceptible to injury from the pressure of the vacuum. Therefore vacuum is contraindicated.
  • Option C: Fetal Coagulopathies: Using vacuum extraction in a baby with a coagulopathy can significantly increase the risk of intracranial hemorrhage and other serious complications due to the added pressure on the baby's head and hence vacuum is contraindicated.
  • Option D: Occipito-Posterior Position (Correct option): Vacuum extraction can be safely and effectively used in many cases of occipito-posterior position, as the position does not inherently increase the risk of complications related to vacuum use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While face presentation, extreme prematurity, and fetal coagulopathies pose significant risks and are generally contraindications for the use of vacuum extraction, the occipito-posterior position does not inherently preclude the safe use of this method.

 

Ref: Page no 1365, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A baby had this complication following a difficult delivery as described by the mother. What could have caused this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Forceps delivery

 

  • This is an image of facial nerve palsy and is more common seen with forceps application as compared to other routes. Brachial plexus injury are also more commonly seen with forceps as compared to vacuum
  • Forceps delivery has higher rates of facial nerve injury, brachial plexus injury, depressed skull fracture, and corneal abrasion
  • Vacuum is associated with more fetal injury overall (especially cephalhematomas, skull fractures, intracranial bleeds, sub galeal hematomas etc).

 

Let us look at each option :

 

  • Option A. Forceps Delivery: The application of forceps can sometimes lead to facial nerve palsy due to the pressure exerted on the baby's face, particularly if the forceps are not positioned or used correctly. This makes forceps delivery a more likely cause of facial nerve palsy compared to other methods.
  • Option B. Vacuum Delivery: Vacuum delivery involves attaching a suction cup to the baby's head and using a vacuum, to assist in guiding the baby through the birth canal. While vacuum delivery can lead to other types of injuries, such as cephalohematoma, intracranial hemorrhage etc it is less likely than forceps delivery to cause facial nerve palsy.
  • Option C. Caesarean Delivery: In a caesarean delivery, the baby is delivered through a surgical incision in the mother's abdomen and uterus. While this method can have its own set of complications, it is unlikely to cause facial nerve palsy
  • Option D: Manual Rotation: Manual rotation is a technique used to reposition the baby within the birth canal to facilitate a smoother delivery. While it involves physical manipulation, it is less likely to cause direct pressure on the baby's face compared to forceps delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of facial nerve palsy following a difficult delivery is Forceps Delivery. This method can exert significant pressure on the baby's face, leading to nerve injury.

 

ReF: Page no 1371, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Transverse perineal muscles

questions.text: Which structure is NOT cut in a mediolateral episiotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obturator muscles

 

Episiotomy

 

  • Episiotomy is a surgical incision of the perineum performed to widen the vaginal opening to facilitate the delivery of an infant.
  • It is one of the most commonly performed procedures on women worldwide.
  • It is performed at crowning
  • Structures cut (From inside out)
    1. Vaginal mucosa
    2. Perineal muscle (superficial and deep transverse perinei, bulbospongiosis and if deep, part of levator ani)
    3. Skin
       

Let us look at each option:

 

  • Option A. Bulbospongiosus: This muscle surrounds the vaginal introitus and is often involved in a mediolateral episiotomy. The incision typically cuts through this muscle to enlarge the vaginal opening for childbirth.
  • Option B. Obturator Muscles: The obturator muscles, located in the pelvis, are not involved in a mediolateral episiotomy. These muscles are deeper and more lateral than the structures typically incised during this procedure.
  • Option C. Transverse Perineal Muscles: These muscles provide support to the pelvic floor and may be partially incised in a mediolateral episiotomy. The incision extends through the perineal body, which includes these muscles.
  • Option D. Perineal Skin: The perineal skin is the outermost layer and is the first structure to be cut in a mediolateral episiotomy. The incision begins at the vaginal opening and extends through the skin and underlying tissues at a mediolateral angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the structure that is NOT cut in a mediolateral episiotomy is B, the Obturator Muscles. These muscles are located deeper and more laterally in the pelvis and are not involved in the episiotomy incision. The purpose of a mediolateral episiotomy is to enlarge the vaginal opening for childbirth, involving an incision through the perineal skin and potentially affecting the bulbospongiosus and transverse perineal muscles.

 

Ref:  Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Long artery forceps
Green Armitage forceps

questions.text: A 23y woman is undergoing a cesarean section for obstructed labor. The head is deeply engaged and delivered with difficulty. Following delivery, you notice that the uterine incision has extended and is bleeding profusely having caused avulsion of the uterine arteries. Which instrument will you use to hold the angles of the uterine incision?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Green Armitage Forceps

 

 

 

  • These are green Armitage forceps
  • They are used to catch the uterine incisions if bleeding profusely
  • They are atraumatic with a wide surface area
  • Normally, the uterine incision is held with an allis forceps

 

Let's look at each of the options provided:

 

  • Option A. Allis Forceps: These forceps are commonly used to grasp or hold tissues, particularly when a firm grip is needed.
  • Option B. Long Artery Forceps: These forceps are designed for clamping blood vessels to control bleeding. While useful in securing bleeding vessels, they might not be the best choice for managing the incision itself, as their primary function is to control bleeding rather than to hold tissue securely for repair.
  • Option C. Babcock Forceps: Babcock forceps are designed to hold delicate tissues without causing significant compression or damage.
  • Option D. Green-Armitage Forceps (correct option): These forceps are specifically designed for obstetrical use, particularly in managing complicated cesarean sections. They are robust and designed to hold the angles of a uterine incision securely, facilitating repair, especially in situations where there is significant extension of the incision and bleeding. Their design allows for a strong grip on the tissue, which is essential in managing such complications.
     

Educational Objective:

 

Green-Armitage Forceps are specially designed for situations encountered in obstetric surgery, such as holding the angles of a uterine incision during a cesarean section with complications like extended incisions and bleeding. They provide the necessary grip and stability to manage the surgical field effectively and safely.

 

Ref: Page no 696, DC Duttas Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: It appears slightly more pink than the upper segment
It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum
It is just below the round ligaments
It is where the presenting part can be palpated

questions.text: A 1st year resident is doing a cesareans section for the 1st time. How will you help her identify the lower uterine segment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum

 

  • During a cesarean procedure, the lower segment has to be identified so that the uterine incision is put on the lower segment (Kerrs incision)
  • This is identified by the loose fold of peritoneum (uterovesical fold) overlying the anterior lower part of the uterus.
  • The UV fold of peritoneum is lifted by an artery forceps, it is then opened transversely, the bladder is pushed down and kept away by putting the Doyens retractor
  • Then the lower uterine incision is given.
     

Let's go through each of the options:

 

  • Option A. It appears slightly more pink than the upper segment: The color difference between the upper and lower segments of the uterus is not typically a reliable indicator for identifying the lower uterine segment.
  • Option B. It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum: This is the correct way to identify the lower uterine segment. The loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum, also known as the vesicouterine pouch, is a peritoneal fold that lies between the bladder and the uterus. The lower uterine segment is located just beneath this fold. During a cesarean section, surgeons look for this anatomical landmark to locate the correct incision site.
  • Option C. It is just below the round ligaments: The round ligaments extend from the uterine fundus to the labia majora and are not reliable landmarks for identifying the lower uterine segment.
  • Option D. It is where the presenting part can be palpated: While the presenting part of the fetus (usually the head) is often located in the lower uterine segment during labor, this is not a reliable method for identifying the lower uterine segment in all cases, especially in situations where the presenting part is not well engaged or in breech presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lower uterine segment in a cesarean section is best identified as the area lying under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum. This anatomical landmark provides a reliable guide for surgeons to make a safe and effective incision, minimizing the risk of injury to the bladder and ensuring optimal surgical outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 1426, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify this instrument shown in the image which is placed vaginally and is used to elevate the fetal head in a difficult cesarean section where the head is deeply engaged:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fetal pillow

 

  • In a deeply engaged head, delivery at cesarean can be difficult and can cause extension of the incisions and bleeding.
  • Several methods have been identified to facilitate delivery of a deeply engaged head. These include
    1. Fetal pillow
    2. An assistant pushes the head up from below
    3. Delivery by Patwardhan maneuver (Delivering the shoulders then the breech then pulling out the head) as shown below

 

Patwardhan maneuver

 

Let us look at the options provided:

 

  • Option A. Fetal Cushion: This term is not commonly associated with the instrument used in cesarean sections for elevating the fetal head
  • Option B. Fetal Pillow (Correct answer) This is a specialized instrument used in cesarean sections to assist with the delivery of a deeply engaged fetal head. It is inserted vaginally and inflated to gently push the fetal head upwards, facilitating a safer and easier delivery. This method reduces the risk of trauma to both the mother and the baby.
  • Option C: Fetal Elevator: While this term sounds plausible, it is not a standard term used for an instrument in cesarean delivery.
  • Option D: Fetal Push: This term does not describe a specific instrument but rather a technique where an assistant may manually push the fetal head up from the vaginal canal to assist with cesarean delivery. This is a more direct and less technologically reliant method compared to using an instrument like the fetal pillow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fetal Pillow, is an instrument used to elevate the fetal head in a difficult cesarean section where the head is deeply engaged. This tool is part of various methods employed to facilitate the safe and efficient delivery of the baby, especially in challenging situations where there is a risk of extension of incisions and bleeding

 

Ref: Page no 1430, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the first structure to be sutured following a median episiotomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucosa

 

An Episiotomy (median or mediolateral) is sutured as follows

 

  1. Vaginal mucosa
  2. Muscle
  3. Skin
     
  • The suture material used is a rapidly absorbable suture (Vicryl rapid or catgut).

 

Let's go through each option:

 

  • Option A. Skin: The skin is the outermost layer and is typically sutured last in an episiotomy repair. The primary goal is to achieve a good cosmetic result and ensure proper healing.
  • Option B. Muscle: The muscles, particularly the perineal muscles, are sutured after the mucosa has been repaired. Suturing the muscle helps in supporting the repair and reducing the risk of long-term complications.
  • Option C. Mucosa (CORRECT): The vaginal mucosa is the first layer to be sutured following episiotomy. The primary reason for starting with the mucosa is to reduce blood loss and to reapproximate the edges of the vaginal lining for better healing. The mucosal layer is delicate and requires careful suturing to ensure proper alignment and healing.
  • Option D. Any layer: False. The order of suturing is typically standardized to ensure optimal healing and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct approach to suturing an episiotomy involves starting with the vaginal mucosa, followed by the muscle layer, and finally the skin. This method ensures effective hemostasis, alignment for optimal healing, and restoration of anatomical and functional integrity of the perineal region. The suture material used is often a rapidly absorbable suture like Vicryl rapid or catgut, which reduces the need for suture removal and provides comfort to the patient

 

Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition
